cards.title: Care about your craft
cards.description: Why spend your life developing software unless you care about doing it well?

cards.title: THINK! about your work
cards.description: Turn off the autopilot and take control. Constantly critique and appraise your work.

cards.title: Provide options, not lame excuses
cards.description: Instead of excuses, provide options. Don't say it can't be done; explain what can be done.

cards.title: Don't live with broken windows
cards.description: Fix bad designs, wrong decisions, and poor code when you see them.

cards.title: Be a catalyst for change
cards.description: You can't force change on people. Instead, show them how the future might be and help them participate in creating it.

cards.title: Make quality part of your requirements
cards.description: Involve your users in determining the project's real quality requirements.

cards.title: Remember the big picture
cards.description: Don't get so engrossed in the details that you forget to check what's happening around you.

cards.title: Invest regularily in your knowledge portfolio
cards.description: Make learning a habit.

cards.title: Critically analyze what you read and hear
cards.description: Don't be swayed by vendors, media hype, or dogma. Analyze information in terms of you and your project.

cards.title: It's both what you say and the way you say it
cards.description: There's no point in having great ideas if you dont communicate them effectively.

cards.title: DRY - Don't Repeat Yourself
cards.description: Every piece of knowledge must have a single, unambiguous, authorative representation within a system.

cards.title: Make it easy to reuse
cards.description: If it's easy to reuse, people will. Create an environment that supports reuse.

cards.title: Eliminate effects between unrelated things
cards.description: Design components that are self-contained, independent, and have a single, well-defined purpose.

cards.title: There are no final decisions
cards.description: No decision is cast in stone. Instead, consider each as being written in the sand at the beach, and plan for change.

cards.title: Use tracer bullets to find the target
cards.description: Tracer bullets let you home in on your target by trying things and seeing how close they land.

cards.title: Prototype to learn
cards.description: Prototyping is a learning experience. Its value lies not in the code you produce, but in the lessons you learn.

cards.title: Program close to the problem domain
cards.description: Design and code in your user's language

cards.title: Estimate to avoid surprises
cards.description: Estimate before you start. You'll spot potential problems up front.

cards.title: Iterate the schedule with the code
cards.description: Use experience you gain as you implement to refine the project time scales.

cards.title: Keep knowledge in plain text
cards.description: Plain text won't become obsolete. It helps leverage your work and simplifies debugging and testing.

cards.title: Use the power of command shells
cards.description: Use the shell when graphical user interfaces don't cut it

cards.title: Use the single editor well
cards.description: The editor should be an extension of your hand: make sure your editor is configurable, extensible and programmable.

cards.title: Always use source control
cards.description: Source code control is a time machine for your work - you can go back.

cards.title: Fix the problem, not the blame
cards.description: It doesn't really matter whether the bug is your fault or someone else's - it's still your problem, and it still needs to be fixed.

cards.title: Don't panic when debugging
cards.description: Take a deep breath and THINK! about what could be causing the bug.

cards.title: 'select' isn't broken
cards.description: It's rare to find a bug in the OS or the compiler, or even a third-party product or library. The bug is most likely in the application.

cards.title: Don't assume it - Prove it
cards.description: Prove your assumptions in the actual environment - with real data and boundary conditions.

cards.title: Learn a text manipulation language
cards.description: You spend a large part of each day working with text. Why not have the computer do some of it for you.

cards.title: Write code that writes code
cards.description: Code generators increase your productivity and help avoid duplication.

cards.title: You can't write perfect software
cards.description: Software can't be perfect. Protect your code and users from the inevitable errors.

cards.title: Design with contracts
cards.description: Use contracts to document and verify that code does no more and no less than it claims to do.

cards.title: Crash early
cards.description: A dead program normally does a lot less damage than a crippled one.

cards.title: Use assertions to prevent the impossible
cards.description: Assertions validate your assumptions. Use them to protect your code from an unceratin world.

cards.title: Use exceptions for exceptional problems
cards.description: Exceptions can suffer from all the readability and maintainability problems of classic spaghetti code. Reserve exceptions for exceptional things.

cards.title: Finish what you start
cards.description: Where possible, the routine or object that allocates a resource should be responsible for deallocating it.

cards.title: Minimize coupling between modules
cards.description: Avoid coupling by writing 'shy' code and applying the Law of Demeter.

cards.title: Configure, don't integrate
cards.description: Implement technology choices for an application as configuration options, not through integration or engineering.

cards.title: Put abstractions in code, details in metadata
cards.description: Program for the general case, and put the specifics outside the compiled code base.

cards.title: Analyze workflow to improve concurrency
cards.description: Exploit concurrency in your user's workflow.

cards.title: Design using services
cards.description: Design in terms of services - independent, concurrent objects behind well-defined, consistent interfaces.

cards.title: Always design for concurrency
cards.description: Allow for concurrency, and you'll design cleaner interfaces with fewer assumptions.

cards.title: Separate views from models
cards.description: Gain flexibility at low cost by designing your application in terms of models and views.

cards.title: Use blackboards to coordinate workflow
cards.description: Use blackboards to coordinate disparate facts and agents, while maintaining independence and isolation among participants.

cards.title: Don't program by coincidence
cards.description: Rely only on reliable things. Beware of accidental complexity, and don't confuse a happy coincidence with a purposeful plan.

cards.title: Estimate the order of your algorithms
cards.description: Get a feel for how long things are likely to take before you write code.

cards.title: Test your estimates
cards.description: Mathematical analysis of algorithms doesn't tell you everything. Try timing your code in its target environment.

cards.title: Refactor early, refactor often
cards.description: Just as you might weed and rearrange a garden; rewrite, rework, and re-architect code when it needs it. Fix the root of the problem.

cards.title: Design to test
cards.description: Start thinking about testing before you write a line of code.

cards.title: Test your software, or your users will
cards.description: Test ruthlessly. Don't make your users find bugs for you.

cards.title: Don't use wizard code you don't understand
cards.description: Wizards can generate reams of code. Make sure you understand all of it before you incorporate it into your project.

cards.title: Don't gather requirements - Dig for them
cards.description: Requirements rarely lie on the surface. They're buried deep beneath layers of assumptions, misconceptions, and politics.

cards.title: Work with a user to think like a user
cards.description: It's the best way to gain insight into how the system will really be used.

cards.title: Abstractions live longer than details
cards.description: Invest in the abstraction, not the implementation. Abstractions can survive the barrage of changes from different implemenations and new technologies.

cards.title: Use a project glossary
cards.description: Create and maintain a single source of all the specific terms and vocabulary for a project.

cards.title: Don't think outside the box - Find the box
cards.description: When faced with an impossible problem, identify the real constraints. Ask yourself: 'Does it have to be done this way? Does it have to be done at all?'

cards.title: Start when you're ready
cards.description: You've been building experience all your life. Don't ignore niggling doubts.

cards.title: Some things are better done than described
cards.description: Don't fall into the specification spiral - At some point you need to start coding.

cards.title: Don't be a slave to formal methods
cards.description: Don't blindly adopt any technique without putting it into the context of your development practices and capabilities.

cards.title: Costly tools don't produce better design
cards.description: Beware of vendor hype, industry dogma, and the aura of the price tag. Judge tools on their merits.

cards.title: Organize teams around functionality
cards.description: Don't separate designers from coders, testers from data modelers. Build teams the way you build code.

cards.title: Don't use manual procedures
cards.description: A shell script or batch file will execute the same instructions, in the same order, time after time.

cards.title: Test early, test often, test automatically
cards.description: Tests that run with every build are much more effective than test plans that sit on a shelf.

cards.title: Coding ain't done 'til all the tests are run
cards.description: 'Nuff said

cards.title: Use saboteurs to test your testing
cards.description: Introduce bugs on purpose in a separate copy of the source to verify that testing will catch them.

cards.title: Test state coverage, not code coverage
cards.description: Identify and test significant program states. Just testing lines of code isn't enough.

cards.title: Find bugs once
cards.description: Once a human tester finds a bug. It should be the last time a human tester finds that bug. Automatic tests should check for it from then on.

cards.title: English is just a programming language
cards.description: Write documents as you would write code: honor the DRY principle, use metadata, MVC, automatic generation, and so on.

cards.title: Build documentation in, don't bolt it on
cards.description: Documentation created separately from code is less likely to be correct and up to date.

cards.title: Gently exceed your users expectations
cards.description: Come to understand your user's expectations, then deliver just that little bit more.

cards.title: Sign your work
cards.description: Craftsmen of an earlier age were proud to sign their work. You should be, too

cards.title: Quesadilla
cards.description: Cheese and chicken in a roll, put it in the oven. What's not to love?
